Thanks in advance!

LIFE DURING WARTIME: A VETERAN SON’S ADDICTION*  

 My name is Sandra Gurvis and I have been a freelance writer for over 25 years. Along with hundreds of magazine articles, I’ve had 15 books published on a wide variety of topics, from travel (DAY TRIPS FROM COLUMBUS, 3rd ed; OHIO CURIOSITIES, 2nd ed.) to business (CAREERS FOR NONCONFORMISTS) to the 1960s (WHERE HAVE ALL THE FLOWER CHILDREN GONE?). I am also the author of two novels: THE PIPE DREAMERS (Olmstead), about student protests on a college campus and COUNTRY CLUB WIVES (Loconeal), a satire on women, money, and homeless animals set in a well-to-do suburb.

 My Indiegogo project is LIFE DURING WARTIME:  A VETERAN SON’S ADDICTION, a unique guidebook for dealing with an addict. A combination of personal experiences and factual information, it will provide a roadmap to the contradictory and terrifying world of addiction, taking the reader step-by-step through the various phases of unfolding realization so common among unsuspecting families and loved ones.  Also, if the reader is angry, frustrated, or afraid, they can look at the table of contents and find a listing that relates to the emotion they are feeling.

 

Backstory

In 2005, my son Alex hurt his back while on active duty in the U.S. Army and as a result, became addicted to oxycontin, and eventually heroin as well as cocaine and crack. Initially I had no clue what was going on, despite what I now realize was glaring evidence of drug abuse. At first, along with the rest of the family, I thought I could fix him. Eventually I went to Al Anon and Nar Anon meetings for support; while they helped somewhat, I still felt isolated and frustrated because there was no single written source for substantive information and emotional enlightenment.

Most of the available material fell into two categories: Literature from NA/AA that provided day-by-day or twelve-step anecdotal information, and technical descriptions of addiction. When I felt angry, frustrated or hopeless, I would frantically search for words or stories that could relate to what I was feeling. And while books such as CODEPENDENT NO MORE and their ilk provided some consolation they still could not fully explain what was happening so I could begin to understand addiction on a rational, in addition to an emotional, level.

I conceived of LIFE DURING WARTIME in 2009, as Alex was in and out of various hospitals and ERs, courts of law, and rehab programs. He nearly lost everything – his wife, several jobs, and almost his life during his last relapse a few months ago. But nothing deterred him, not even the very real possibility of state prison (as opposed to the county jail – where he’d already spent some time) or the fact that his first cousin Josh died of an overdose in 2008. I kept thinking that if I paid for this medicine or that bill or even some groceries and cigarettes that he would get help as he’d so often promised and be cured. But it only got worse. Bad people came after him and needed to be paid off; some even showed up at my front door. I didn’t want my son to die, so I did whatever I could to save him.

 

Addiction is Hell

Prescription drug abuse is rampant in the United States, among both civilians and veterans. Over the past two years, more soldiers have committed suicide than died in Iraq and Afghanistan, often because of overdose and/or inability to manage physical and mental pain. And every 19 minutes, someone in the US dies from a prescription drug overdose, triple the rate in 1990. In the state of Ohio alone, in 2010, 67 pills were dispensed for each resident, a total of over 776 million pills.  Of these, only 5 percent were dispensed legally – the majority were given free, stolen, or purchased from a friend or relative. In fact, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more people are killed from ingesting painkillers such as oxycodone than from cocaine and heroin combined.

Families and loved ones who are first exposed to the reality of drug abuse are understandably shocked by talk of jail, homelessness and the ICU (and worse), all of which are very real consequences. They may feel that relapses or inability to control addiction are a moral failing on their part or that of the addict. Too often they turn their backs on support groups like NA and AA because what is shared at meetings runs counterintuitive to what they instinctively want to do, which is “rescue” their loved one.

When I was going through this process, I found great solace in attending seminars and informational programs which were mostly geared towards healthcare providers. I began to glean a pattern, logic, and commonality of symptoms. Support groups also helped when others shared their stories, insights, and provided comfort. Yet when I was alone and wanted to read something that would hone in on a particular emotion or question, there were only general sources to turn to.  LIFE DURING WARTIME aims to bridge these gaps, combining all this information into a single, useful source.

 

Saving Soldiers’ Lives -- Helping Families of Addicts

I have many contacts in the publishing industry, a platform for and extensive experience in author promotion, and a professional background in all aspects of writing, editing and book creation. I am the author of 15 other books, many of which have been successful, gone into multiple editions, and are still in print. Perhaps more importantly, I have been given an ability to write passionately and clearly about my experiences and share this knowledge with others. If more come to understand that in many ways, addiction is no different from Alzheimer’s or even heart disease, they can begin to realize that there are steps to take towards specific treatments. Although there are no easy answers, asking the right questions and achieving insight can help illuminate the way.

Soldiers have many more obstacles than even the average addict. I have seen Alex devolve from a confident, gregarious, and energetic young man willing to take chances to someone who basically keeps to himself. Because of his physical and mental health problems, he believes that his initial dream of becoming a police officer is over forever. While he is currently in recovery, it is day-by-day.

For the past several years, the US has deployed tens of thousands of soldiers to fight in Iraq and Afghanistan as well as serve stateside. Some may or may not have been injured or may or may not even seen combat. But most of them enlisted with the ideals and hope that they would preserve freedom for this country. And what they got, when they suffered post-traumatic stress syndrome (PTSD) or experienced any other physical or emotional pain, was oxycodene (oxycontin) and other members of the opioid family -- Fentanyl, Vicodin, as well as hydromorphines (Dilaudid) and even morphine. And in many cases that lead straight to abuse, heroin and hell.

Veteran’s Administrations and other treatment centers and hospitals are overwhelmed.  While they do the best they can, many times families and veterans don’t know where to turn.  They may feel overwhelmed by paperwork or not know where to go to get help and social services. If you don’t know how or where to ask the right questions, how can you get answers?  LIFE DURING WARTIME will provide resources for these issues as well. 

 

How the Project Works

Phase I:  Initial book proposal and sample chapters

In this first phase, I am seeking funds to prepare a proposal and sample chapters of LIFE DURING WARTIME to pitch to agents and editors at the American Society of Journalists and Authors' annual conference (ASJA, www.asja.org) in New York City in April 2013.  Additionally, I have received a partial two-week fellowship to work on this project.  Regardless of how much is raised, however, all monies will be put towards completion of the sample chapters, outline and table of contents so they can be submitted to editors and agents in the spring of 2013.

Should I receive a standard book contract and advance, any leftover funds  will go towards promotion and publicity.

Phase 2: Completing the project as an ebook

This phase will only be implemented if the book does not receive a standard publishing contract/advance.  I will use any leftover monies from Phase I as well as seek additional funds to finish LIFE DURING WARTIME independently and publish it as an ebook. Monies will be raised to allow me time to complete the book and hire a cover designer and copy editor/proofreader, with the balance being used to promote the ebook.

 

What you get

Donors starting at $10 have their choice of either a free Kindle download of my novel THE PIPE DREAMERS or a download of LIFE AFTER WARTIME after it is published. I will dedicate the book to those donating the maximum of $500, in addition to speaking to their group or organization.  Those who contribute $100 will have their name or designee incorporated into the cover design.  Any and all contributors are welcome to share their stories for the book so we can come together as a community to solve this problem.

But the intangible perks – especially for those who’ve ever loved an addict or experienced addiction firsthand – far outweigh anything that I can personally give you. Knowing that we’ve all worked towards creating a resource that can help understand and deal with addiction is the best reward.  Stopping one overdose or helping one family member or loved one is enough.

*Please note:  Because of Hurricane Sandy and its aftermath, a minimum of 5-7 percent of any funds raised after 11/6/12 will be donated to disaster relief.  If the entire amount is raised, I will donate 12 percent.  I want to do what I can to help those who are in such deep distress. Thanks in advance!
LIFE DURING WARTIME: A VETERAN SON’S ADDICTION*  
 My name is Sandra Gurvis and I have been a freelance writer for over 25 years. Along with hundreds of magazine articles, I’ve had 15 books published on a wide variety of topics, from travel (DAY TRIPS FROM COLUMBUS, 3rd ed; OHIO CURIOSITIES, 2nd ed.) to business (CAREERS FOR NONCONFORMISTS) to the 1960s (WHERE HAVE ALL THE FLOWER CHILDREN GONE?). I am also the author of two novels: THE PIPE DREAMERS (Olmstead), about student protests on a college campus and COUNTRY CLUB WIVES (Loconeal), a satire on women, money, and homeless animals set in a well-to-do suburb.
 My Indiegogo project is LIFE DURING WARTIME:  A VETERAN SON’S ADDICTION, a unique guidebook for dealing with an addict. A combination of personal experiences and factual information, it will provide a roadmap to the contradictory and terrifying world of addiction, taking the reader step-by-step through the various phases of unfolding realization so common among unsuspecting families and loved ones.  Also, if the reader is angry, frustrated, or afraid, they can look at the table of contents and find a listing that relates to the emotion they are feeling.
 
Backstory
In 2005, my son Alex hurt his back while on active duty in the U.S. Army and as a result, became addicted to oxycontin, and eventually heroin as well as cocaine and crack. Initially I had no clue what was going on, despite what I now realize was glaring evidence of drug abuse. At first, along with the rest of the family, I thought I could fix him. Eventually I went to Al Anon and Nar Anon meetings for support; while they helped somewhat, I still felt isolated and frustrated because there was no single written source for substantive information and emotional enlightenment.
Most of the available material fell into two categories: Literature from NA/AA that provided day-by-day or twelve-step anecdotal information, and technical descriptions of addiction. When I felt angry, frustrated or hopeless, I would frantically search for words or stories that could relate to what I was feeling. And while books such as CODEPENDENT NO MORE and their ilk provided some consolation they still could not fully explain what was happening so I could begin to understand addiction on a rational, in addition to an emotional, level.
I conceived of LIFE DURING WARTIME in 2009, as Alex was in and out of various hospitals and ERs, courts of law, and rehab programs. He nearly lost everything – his wife, several jobs, and almost his life during his last relapse a few months ago. But nothing deterred him, not even the very real possibility of state prison (as opposed to the county jail – where he’d already spent some time) or the fact that his first cousin Josh died of an overdose in 2008. I kept thinking that if I paid for this medicine or that bill or even some groceries and cigarettes that he would get help as he’d so often promised and be cured. But it only got worse. Bad people came after him and needed to be paid off; some even showed up at my front door. I didn’t want my son to die, so I did whatever I could to save him.
 
Addiction is Hell
Prescription drug abuse is rampant in the United States, among both civilians and veterans. Over the past two years, more soldiers have committed suicide than died in Iraq and Afghanistan, often because of overdose and/or inability to manage physical and mental pain. And every 19 minutes, someone in the US dies from a prescription drug overdose, triple the rate in 1990. In the state of Ohio alone, in 2010, 67 pills were dispensed for each resident, a total of over 776 million pills.  Of these, only 5 percent were dispensed legally – the majority were given free, stolen, or purchased from a friend or relative. In fact, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more people are killed from ingesting painkillers such as oxycodone than from cocaine and heroin combined.
Families and loved ones who are first exposed to the reality of drug abuse are understandably shocked by talk of jail, homelessness and the ICU (and worse), all of which are very real consequences. They may feel that relapses or inability to control addiction are a moral failing on their part or that of the addict. Too often they turn their backs on support groups like NA and AA because what is shared at meetings runs counterintuitive to what they instinctively want to do, which is “rescue” their loved one.
When I was going through this process, I found great solace in attending seminars and informational programs which were mostly geared towards healthcare providers. I began to glean a pattern, logic, and commonality of symptoms. Support groups also helped when others shared their stories, insights, and provided comfort. Yet when I was alone and wanted to read something that would hone in on a particular emotion or question, there were only general sources to turn to.  LIFE DURING WARTIME aims to bridge these gaps, combining all this information into a single, useful source.
 
Saving Soldiers’ Lives -- Helping Families of Addicts
I have many contacts in the publishing industry, a platform for and extensive experience in author promotion, and a professional background in all aspects of writing, editing and book creation. I am the author of 15 other books, many of which have been successful, gone into multiple editions, and are still in print. Perhaps more importantly, I have been given an ability to write passionately and clearly about my experiences and share this knowledge with others. If more come to understand that in many ways, addiction is no different from Alzheimer’s or even heart disease, they can begin to realize that there are steps to take towards specific treatments. Although there are no easy answers, asking the right questions and achieving insight can help illuminate the way.
Soldiers have many more obstacles than even the average addict. I have seen Alex devolve from a confident, gregarious, and energetic young man willing to take chances to someone who basically keeps to himself. Because of his physical and mental health problems, he believes that his initial dream of becoming a police officer is over forever. While he is currently in recovery, it is day-by-day.
For the past several years, the US has deployed tens of thousands of soldiers to fight in Iraq and Afghanistan as well as serve stateside. Some may or may not have been injured or may or may not even seen combat. But most of them enlisted with the ideals and hope that they would preserve freedom for this country. And what they got, when they suffered post-traumatic stress syndrome (PTSD) or experienced any other physical or emotional pain, was oxycodene (oxycontin) and other members of the opioid family -- Fentanyl, Vicodin, as well as hydromorphines (Dilaudid) and even morphine. And in many cases that lead straight to abuse, heroin and hell.
Veteran’s Administrations and other treatment centers and hospitals are overwhelmed.  While they do the best they can, many times families and veterans don’t know where to turn.  They may feel overwhelmed by paperwork or not know where to go to get help and social services. If you don’t know how or where to ask the right questions, how can you get answers?  LIFE DURING WARTIME will provide resources for these issues as well.

story:
Our Story

Authorâ€™s Launch is a site for writers and those who enjoy discovering the next great writer. We just need the funding to give it a push in the right direction.

By bundling technology and people, we are changing the concept of a traditional book club and how writers are discovered.

The first question an author hears from publishers or agents is, â€œWhatâ€™s your platform?â€ Authorâ€™s Launch was developed to create that platform. Many would think this is a great time to become an author. It isn't.

But it can be. And that starts with finding good writing.

The writers we select can say they were chosen, they were published and that they have had their work exposed to an audience of members from over 30 countries around the world.

Writers need a place to get their work seen by a multitude of eyes, in an easy-to-find and digest format. Authorâ€™s Launch will give them that and more. We will discover talented authors through submissions, social media and good old fashioned networking and turn their work over to a community hungry for innovative and inspired writing.

Each author will have tailored events, their book released and distributed, a chance to interact with a community of readers through conference calls, screen sharing/classroom technology and bulletin boards, as well as PR and marketing from social media and other sources.

From the other side, readers often ask, "How did these people get a book deal?"

We are empowering readers in over two dozen nations to answer that question: "Because I helped them get started."

Members can interact directly with authors about their work. Regardless of your schedule or location, you will be able to speak with and contact other members to share your views as part of the membership.

We plan to release 24 ebooks in the first year (two per month).

In these times of a tough economies around the world, we have also reached out to libraries in test markets to allow the books and the site to live organically across the United States and, in a sense, get independent writers on the bookshelves of libraries.


The Impact

Our plan is to connect authors and readers throughout the world in a unique blend of online and real-world applications, including on-site events, simulcast library meetings, authorsâ€™ readings in independent bookstores broadcast over the web, and more. We want to take the local and make it universalâ€”an idea integral to the writing process itself.

As you help us make this successful, we will show that people can help determine what is good in the marketplace--and not what the marketplace wants people to think is good. We can directly formulate and shape the next generation of great authors.


What We Need & What You Get

We're looking for $20,000 to get started. That would be enough to get initial marketing and advertising materials pulled together, a staff of strong individuals, a powerful website complete with our forum and screensharing software online and some great authors on board for our first year. Money will be going directly to creating and hosting the site and then to finding our first batch of submissions.


Other Ways You Can Help

Talk about our site. Help us evolve and formulate the idea. This is not our mom's book club. We truly feel that reading has a place in everyone's lives, and this offers everyone the chance to find great books and share those books with others on a broader scale. I believe in social media, and I believe in readers and writers, and feel that if those could be brought together, great things can happen.

story:
Ghost Shadow: Unfinished Sins

What Do I Need?

   While there are many ways to achieve promotion of this novel at low cost or no lost, there are several areas where immediate cash will be required.

      • I need to purchase and ship copies of the novel for reviewers across Canada and in the United States.  It's also possible that certain influential international reviewers may be interested. Example:cost to mail one review copy, on average, about $32.50 (novel=$18.99, packaging and inserts=$2.00, postage=$8.00-$15.00).  It doesn't take many review copies for that to really add up.
      • While some bookstores will purchase books for launches and signings, there's a possibility I may need to buy back unsold books at cost. (I will do my best to make sure no book goes unsold.)
      • In bookstores where I self-book a reading and signing (in effect, borrow the store's space) I may have to purchase the books to sell and bring them with me.
      • I'd like to organize a promotional tour to bookstores in cities across Canada or, at the very least, across the provinces of Ontario and Quebec, the two with the largest book-reading populations.  While I would travel on a slim budget, travel expenses still need to be paid.
      • For launches, signings, or a bookstore tour, promotional needs such as posters, promotional cards, and advertisements must be paid for, usually in advance in the case of advertisements.

What Can I Do For You? 

      • For any amount, from one dollar up, you will receive my eternal gratitude.  
      • For any amount over $30, I will also send you a copy of the novel direct from the printer.  
      • For any amount over $50, I will send you a personally signed copy of the novel.  
      • For any amount over $75, I will also send you a copy of Poem de Terre's most recent CD release, War & Love, featuring my words spoken and sung over original music.  
      • For any amount over $100, I will also send you a personally signed early copy of the next novel in this series when it is published.  
      • For for these and further gifts, please check the VIP Perks section in green at the right side of this page.
      • Is there anything else I can do for you?  Tell me about it and let's see what we can work out.

How Else Can You Help?

      • Using Facebook, Twitter, e-mail lists, or any way you can, let others know about this project listing on IndiGoGo.
      • Also spread the word about this novel and let people know it's available at online bookstores (or will be in about a week).
      • Take some time to read the preview scenes and discover something of what this story is all about.
      • Tell all your friends, co-workers, and acquaintances about this novel.
      • Include this novel to discuss at your book club.
      • If you have the time or can provide any products or services to help promote this novel, please let me know.  (We'll attach a cash-value so you can enjoy the thank you gifts listed above.)

What's the Project?

    Ghost Shadow: Unfinished Sins is a taut, suspenseful thriller strongly influenced by writers such as Raymond Chandler, Graham Greene, and Elmore Leonard.  Here's a synopsis of the novel as printed on the front page of the book's e-store:

     In mid-Eighties Windsor, Vietnamese gangs and Chinese organized crime meet head on in violent turf war as they go after a University of Windsor anthropology professor and $2,000,000 in ancient treasure he stole from China. Meanwhile, a brutal serial rapist and killer terrorizes the city. 

     Three psychologically damaged women - the professor's wife, his 17 year old daughter, and a private detective - are drawn into this world of brutal psychological terror, raw physical and emotional violence, and international crime and intrigue. Can they survive?

     In the tradition of Graham Greene and Elmore Leonard. Working on several levels, this psychological crime thriller is also the story of how these three women cope and ultimately survive their journey into hell.

     Payge Turner was considered a good cop. At least she was until she was asked to leave the Windsor Police Force for an unprovoked angry attack on a suspect. Payge has a darkness in her that made her dangerous to work with and difficult to control.

     Now Payge is a private detective. It's easier to control her darkness when she works alone.

     Payge's mind is on the current rash of brutal rape-murders in Windsor when she is hired to investigate the disappearance of 17 year old Susan Markham, the daughter of a respected anthropologist. Susan doesn't fit the rapist's M.O., but Payge begins to suspect something more sinister has happened to this attractive student.

     Within days, Payge must cope with the turf war between oriental gangs, stolen Chinese treasure, a father who seems unconcerned that his daughter has been kidnapped, and a client who isn't telling her everything. The dark streets of Windsor hide secrets in bars, in families, in the shaded corners where rapists hide.

     Joining forces with her old police partner, Yvonne Laforet, Payge is soon on the trail of the missing woman. What she doesn't realize is that the most frightening thing she'll discover is hidden deep within herself.

     The novel is about to be released for sale.  It will be available at Amazon, Barnes and Noble, and other respected online bookstores as well as at Barnes and Noble and other bricks-and-mortar bookstores across North America.  Book launches are planned at bookstores in Kingston and Windsor, Ontario, to be followed by launches and book signings in cities across Canada.  The first official launch will be held on October 14, 2010 at Novel Idea, an independent bookstore in Kingston, Ontario.  This launch will be hosted by local author Violette Malan, who is very supportive of this novel.  Book reviews are now being solicited and several reviewers have already agreed to read ands review the book.  Other media promotion, such as interviews with the author, is also being arranged in the near future.

   You can also read previews of several scenes from the novel, available online.

   While I have published prose fiction before, this will be my first published novel.  If it is successful, it will pave the way for future novel publications.  In fact, this story is meant to be the first in a series featuring the same detective.  This may also benefit other authors.  As a member of the Canadian writing community, I am aware of a number of excellent novelists who have high quality, sellable novel manuscripts which are not being published by the big firms.  In the process of publishing my own novel, I've set up an imprint, Dark Matter Press, to publish not just my own writing but that of others as well.  As this novel is a test-case for my own series, it is also a test-case for Dark Matter Press.  With successful publication and marketing of this first novel, I will be able to publish other authors in the future.

Who Am I?

     My name is  Bob MacKenzie.  I am a widely published Canadian poet and arts journalist (reviews and commentary) and a performer of words with music.  I have published hundreds of poems across North America.in magazines and journals as well as many anthologies.  To date, I have published six books of poetry and prose fiction and six albums of my performances with the group Poem de Terre.  Check me out at the A Canadian Poet website or go direct to my Arts Biography.  In addition to being an established literary writer, I have a strong background in print and broadcast media, marketing, and publishing.  Recently, I decided to self-publish my novel Ghost Shadow: Unfinished Sins, a psychological thriller set in the Canadian border community of Windsor, Ontario.  Just under the surface, even a peaceful Canadian border city has its dark side.
